title-group.article-title: Improving vehicle ride comfort using an active and semi-active controller in a half-car model

article-meta.aff: 1School of Automotive Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, Tehran, Iran
2School of Automotive Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Iranian Automobile Manufacturing Co., (SAIPA) Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: J Marzbanrad, School of Automotive Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Narmak, 16846-13114, Tehran, Iran Email: marzban@iust.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, fuzzy logic control of a vehicle suspension with magneto rheological damper on a random road is considered. To simulate road roughness height a filtered white noise is employed and a four degree-of-freedom, half-car model is used in the analysis. A sensor mounted in the front of the vehicle is responsible for measuring the road irregularities at some distances in the front of the vehicle. Some other sensors are used to measure relative velocities of the vehicle body with respect to unsprung masses in wheel travel spaces. All measurements are assumed to be conducted in a noisy environment. The state variable of the simulated vehicle are calculated, using a method which is similar to the Kalman filter. To have a tailored estimation of magneto rheological damper performance a model which is known as Bouc-Wen is adopted. In addition, utilization of genetic algorithm (GA) in elicitation of fuzzy rules and tuning membership function is exhibited. This controller is a combination of fuzzy controller as a feed back and preview controller as a feed-forward controller, so as to anticipate irregularities of the road. Furthermore, GA is used to determine the optimized preview time. The typical parameters of fuzzy controller are encoded into a chromosome represented as an integer string. Then, by evaluating a multi objective function using a non dominated sorting GA II the superior chromosomes are elected and as a result, the optimized fuzzy logic controller can be employed. Also, by implementation of the combined controller which is designed by GA, it is possible to obtain better performances for the Fuzzy Interface System or, at the same performances, a less complex structure for the system. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm has been verified through a series of simulations for a former designed controller.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: While a great number of papers have been published concerning active and semi-active suspension, in recent decades using feed-forward control (preview) has attracted remarkable attention. Preview active control of suspension involves the acquisition and use of information concerning the road profile ahead of the vehicle. It was first Bender (1968) who proposed the application of preview control so as to improve vehicle suspension performance. Tomizuka (1974, 1975, 1976) described the implementation aspect of the preview control of suspension in practice.

Thompson et al. (1980) and Pilbeam and Sharp (1996) used a state space approach and analyzed the suspension control for a quarter car model. Sasaki et al. (1975), Iwata and Nakano (1976), Foag and Grubel (1987), Sharp and Wilson (1990) and Louam et al. (1992) considered a two dimensional half-car model, which is supported by front and rear suspensions.

Crolla and Abdel-Hadi (1991), Marzbanrad et al. (2002, 2003) and Fruhauf et al. (2007) used a full-car configuration and analyzed the active control of suspension with the use of preview information. Morita et al. (1992) discussed the problems associated with the practical aspect of sensing the preview information. In preview active control of suspension there are two sets of variables that need to be sensed and used in the control scheme. Preview of road irregularity information is used as the feed forward component of the control strategy, while the state variables of the suspension system provide the basis for the feedback part of the control scheme. In most previous studies on preview active control, it was assumed that all state variables are measured and the effect of the noisy environment was ignored. Thompson (1984) noted the difficulties associated with measuring all state variables in practical applications. In this paper, to control the stationary response of a half-car model to a random excitation two magneto rheological (MR) dampers are used. For having a smooth ride and not disturbing handling parameters such as tire holding, input current to MR dampers should be adjusted to the acceptable level. First, to predict the vibration isolation performance of MR damper the mechanical models must be known. Many models such as the Bingham model (Phillips, 1969), the Herscher-Bulkley viscosity-plastic model (Yang, 2001), the Bouc-Wen phenomenological model (Switonski, 2007; Mohammad, 2009), the modified Dahl model (Pang and Kamath, 1998) and polynomial models have been proposed in the literature. Among them, the Bouc-Wen model is the most accurate and commonly used, and many modified forms in the base of this model have been developed. The MR damper parameters of the model used in many investigations match an actual damper fabricated by the Lord Corporation. They are determined such that the model characteristics fit very closely the experimental hysteretic behavior of the MR damper. The response of the vehicle model with the MR dampers to the random road excitation are obtained using the equivalent linearization technique in an iterative manner. Since the aim of this study is to compare the efficiency of the semi-active MR damper to that of an active suspension, the response of the half-car vehicle model using fuzzy logic control (FLC) with and without preview is obtained. As fuzzy logic can express the abstract meaning of natural languages and a qualitative thinking process of humans, FLC has been widely used in the control of numerous processes which cannot be controlled by the traditional control theories (Baillie, 1999). In the FLC, however, it is very grueling for human experts to construct the rule bases, and the number and center values of membership functions. GA provides a way of overcoming some deficiencies and shortcomings associated with FLC. A number of studies have applied GA in order to optimize fuzzy logic controller to ease the process of deriving and tuning fuzzy rule base and membership functions. Herrera et al. (1995) in an attempt to optimize a rule base of FLC for which the membership functions have already been specified used GA. However, Lee and Takagi (1993) utilize GA to determine the number of membership functions. In both of these papers, the GA has employed real-valued encodings, whereas Belarbi and Titel (2000) used binary encoding for their approach. For developing desired fuzzy control, because membership functions and fuzzy rule bases are interrelated, rules and membership functions should not be considered independently, that is why optimal design would be the tuning and designing of all parameters associated with fuzzy control together. Park et al. (1995) implemented a GA by using characteristic parameters to automate FLC design. Using this technique, an FLC can be designed easily. Cheong and Lai (2000) employed GA to derive rule-bases that were well-formed and the method used was proven to be efficient. This paper has tried to make a comparative study so as to understand some benefits and deficiencies of the active fuzzy controller, in comparison to the semi-active with MR damper.

sec.title: 2. Suspension model
sec.p:
Generally, the vehicle suspension models may be divided into three types namely quarter-car, half-car and full-car models. In the quarter-car model, the model is based on the interaction between the quarter car body and the single wheel. The motion of the quarter-car model is only in the vertical direction and for the half-car model; the interactions are between the car body and the wheel and also between both ends of the car body. The first interaction in the half-car models caused the vertical motion and the second interaction produced an angular motion. In the full-car model, the interactions are between the car body and the four wheels that generated the vertical motion, between the car body and the left and right wheels that generated an angular motion called rolling and between the car body and the front and rear wheels that produced the pitch motion. Here in this study the half-car suspension model is taken as shown in Figures 1 and 2. Figure 1.
Block diagram of a half-car model for suspension system.
Figure 2.
Semi-active suspension system (a) Half-car with magneto rheological damper (b) The magneto rheological damper model.

sec.title: 2.1. Half-car model
sec.p:
A half-car model as shown in Figures 1 and 2(a) is used in the present study. The model has four degrees-of-freedom, including the vertical motions for unsprung masses of front and rear wheels and motions of the sprung mass including heave and pitch. The MR damper is modeled by the modified Bouc-Wen hysteretic model shown in Figure 2(b) with the following equations: (1)Ff=Kf(yc+aθ-yf)-(Uf)MR;Fr=Kr(yc-bθ-yr)-(Ur)MR;
(2)My··c+Ff+Fr=0
(3)Iθ··+Ffa-Frb=0
(4)mfy··f+Ktf(yf-hf)-Ff=0;mry··r+Ktr(yr-hr)-Fr=0
The block diagram of Figure 1 shows the relations of each component in the simulation.

In equations (1) to (4), I is the mass moment inertia of the vehicle body with respect to center of gravity (C.G.), M is the sprung mass of the vehicle body, mf and mr are the unsprung masses, yc is the absolute displacement of the CG of the vehicle body (sprung mass), yf and yr are the unsprung mass displacements, θ is the pitch, Kf and Kr are passive suspension stiffnesses, Cf and Cr are passive suspension damping coefficients, Ktf and Ktr are the tire stiffnesses, hf and hr are the random road excitations, (Uf)MR and (Ur)MR are the control forces generated by the MR dampers. In all these quantities the subscripts f and r refer to the front and rear ends of the vehicle respectively and MR refers to the MR damper. a and b are the distances of the front and rear ends from the CG of the vehicle. The control forces generated by the front (Uf)MR and rear (Ur)MR MR dampers represented in Figure 2 are given by equations (5) and (6). (5)(Uf)MR=K2f(yf-yc-aθ)+C2f(y·1f-y·c-aθ·)
(6)(Ur)MR=K2r(yr-yc+bθ)+C2r(y·1r-yc+bθ·)

The velocity components y·1fand y·1r in equations (7) and (8) respectively are given by (7)y·1f=1C1f+C2f(K1f(yf-y1f)+C1fy·f+C2f(y·c+aθ·)-α1fz1f)
(8)y·1r=1C1r+C2r(K1r(yr-y1r)+C1ry·r+C2r(y·c-bθ·)-α1rz1r)

The hysteretic displacements z1f and z1r are assumed to be governed by the modified Bouc-Wen model given by (Bouc, 1967; Baber and Wen, 1981; Prabakar et al., 2009). (9)z·1f=-γ1f|y·1f-y·f|z1f|z1f|(n-1) -β1f(y·1f-y·f)|z1f|(n)+A1f(y·1f-y·f)
(10)z·1r=-γ1r|y·1r-y·r|z1r|z1r|(n-1) -β1r(y·1r-y·r)|z1r|(n)+A1r(y·1r-y·r)

The parameters α1f,γ1f,, β1f and A1f, are considered constant parameters for the front model of MR damper and α1r,γ1r,, β1r and A1r, in equation (10) are constant parameters for the rear MR damper. Details of the parameters can be found in some previous works as Spencer (1996), Yang (2001), Domingnez et al. (2006) and Prabakar et al. (2009). K1f and K2f are the stiffness, C1f and C2f are the damping coefficients and y1f and y·1f are the displacement and velocity of the front MR damper model, also K1r, K2r, C1r, C2r are stiffness and damping corresponding to the rear MR damper. In addition, displacement and velocity related to rear MR damper are shown with y1r and y·1r. n in equations (9) and (10) is the parameter representing the smoothness of transition from elastic to plastic response. The variables C1f, C2f and α1f are given as a function of input current A, C1f=C1fa+C1fbA, C2f=C2fa+C2fbA and α1f=α1fa+α1fbA. C1fa, C2fa and α1fa are associated with passive suspension, it means when the input current, A, is zero, C2f and C1f correspond to the passive suspension. The relations, referred above, are for the front MR damper and similar relations apply to the rear MR damper with the subscript f replaced by r. It is assumed that identical MR dampers are used at the front and the rear, that is, α1f=α1r; γ1f=γ1r; β1f=β1r; A1f=A1r; K1f=K1r; K2f=K2r; C1f=C1r; C2f=C2r;

sec.title: 2.2. Road profile
sec.p:
Procedures for simulating road surface profiles are consistent with the available measurements have been reported by Robson et al. (1979), Ruf (1978), and Cebon and Newland (1983). In this paper, the road surface elevation power spectral density suggested by Rotenberg (1972) which is applicable for a number of roads, is used as equation (11): (11)Sw(ω)=Rvω2+v2(ϕ12+aϕ121+α)ω4+(ϕ12+ϕ22)v2ω2+ϕ12ϕ22v4 where ω is the angular frequency, v is the vehicle velocity, α1, α2, β, σ12, σ22 are the coefficients depending on the type of road/train. The values of parameters for paved roads that are used in this study are listed in Table 1. ϕ1 and ϕ2 are road roughness parameters which are assumed to be 0.45 m-1 and 0.45 m-1 respectively, and R corresponds to the road surface irregularity height variance. The time history of the road excitation corresponding to the spectral intensity given by equation (11) can be generated by passing a white noise process through a linear third order filter given as (12)w··+a1w·+a2w=ζ·+a3ζ
Table 1.
Parameter values for spectrum of paved road
α1(m−1) α2(m−1) β(m−1) σ12(m2) σ22(m2)
0.5 0.2 2.0 2.55 × 10−4 4.5 × 10−3
The filter equation (18) may be presented in a matrix form as (19)F2w=[01-a2-a1] and (20)D2w=[1-a1+a3]
In equation (12), ζ, is a scalar white noise process. In this study, the intensity of ζ is selected so that the random road has a surface irregularity, standard deviation of 0.01m.

sec.title: 2.3. Equivalent linearization technique
sec.p:
Equivalent linearization as derived by Iwan and Yang (1972) is applied for equations (19) and (20) to simplify vehicle MR damper model. Prabaker et al. (2009) Reji and Narayana (2005) have used this technique to simulate MR damper. Equivalent linearization equations are given by equations (21) and (22) (Hurdato and Barbat 2000): (21)z·1f=-Chf(y·1f-y·f)-Khfz1f
(22)z·1r=-Chr(y·1r-y·r)-Khrz1r where Chf and Chr are the equivalent damping coefficients for the front and rear MR dampers, respectively and Khf and Khf are the equivalent stiffness for the front and rear MR dampers, obtained by minimizing the mean square equation error. yf and yr are the unsprung mass displacements (Baber and Wen, 1981). (23)Chf=2π[γ1fE[(y·1f-y·f)z1f]E[(y·1f-y·f)]+β1fE[z1f]]-A1f
(24)Khf=2π[β1fE[(y·1f-y·f)z1f]E[(z1f)]+γ1fE[(y·1f-y·1)]]
(25)Chr=2π[γ1rE[(y·1r-y·r)z1r]E[(z·1r-z·r)]+β1rE[z1r]]-A1r
(26)Khr=2π[β1rE[(y·1r-y·f)z1r]E[(z1r)]+γ1rE[(y·1r-y·r)]]

sec.title: 2.4. State space representation
sec.p: The state variables for the half-car vehicle model with semi-active suspension system are given by yc, y·c, θ, θ·, yf, y·f, yr, y·r, y1f, z1f, y1r, z1r, hf, hr. equations (1) to (10) and equations (21) to (26) are representing the vehicle model and equations (12) and (13) representing the road inputs at the front and rear wheels respectively. They can be put together to yield an augmented system of equations expressed as equation (27). (27)X·a=FXa+Dw

The system matrices [F], [D] and w=[w1,w2] represented in the equations (27) to (31) are given by (28)F=[FxDx0Fd]
(29)[Fx]=[FX1FX3FX2FX4],D=[0NV×10NV×11001]

[w] matrix in the state equation (27) is the input and [F] is the state matrix, [D] in that state equation is also output matrix. Aforementioned state variables have been labeled by [Xa]. In equation (29) Nv is the number of state variables in the vehicle model, e.g, Nv=8 is for active suspension system and Nv=12 for semi-active MR suspension system, and Dx and Fd are as follow: (30)[Dx]=[00000Ktfmf000000000Ktrmr];[Fd]=[-αrV00-αrV]

For the active suspension system, the system matrix [F] contains [Fx1] and [Fx2] as: (31)M-aCf-bCrMkfMCfMkrMCrM00010000-(akf-bkr)I-(aCf-bCr)I-(a2kf+b2kr)I-(a2Cf+b2Cr)I-aKfI-aCfI-bKrI-bCrI]
(32)[Fx2]=[00000100KfmfCfmfaKfmfaCfmf-(Kf+Ktf)mf-Cfmf0000000001krmrCrmr-bKrmr-bCrmr00-(Kr+Ktr)mr-Crmr]
(33)[Fx11]=[010-Kr-K2f-K2r-KfM-C2f-C2r+C2f2+C2r2/(C1f+C2f)Mb(Kr+K2r)-a(Kf+K2f)M000-(aKf+K2f)+b(Kr+K2r)IC2f2a/(C1f+C2f)-C2r2b/(C1r+C2r)+C2rb-C2faI-a2(Kf+K2f)-b2(Kr+K2r)I000Kf+K2fmf(C2f-C2f2/(C1f+c2f))mfa(Kf+K2f)mf]
(34)[Fx12]=[000(-C2fa+C2rb)+(C2f2b-C2f2a)/(C1f+C2f)M(Kf+K2f)+(C2fK1f)/(C1f+C2f)MC2fC1f/(C1f+C2f)M100(C2f2)/(C1f+C2f)-C2f)a2+(C2r2)/(C1r+C2r)-C2r)a2Ia(Kf+K2f+C2fK1f/(C1f+C2f))I(C2fC1fa/(C1f+C2f))I001a(C2f-(C2f2/(C1f+C2f)))mf(-Ktf-Kf-K2f-(C2fK1f)/(C1f+C2f))mf(-(C2fC1f/C1f+C2f))mf]
(35)[Fx2]=[000000(Kr+K2r)mr(C2r-(C2r2/(C1r+C2r)))mr-b(Kr+K2r)mrb(-C2r+(C2r2/C1r+C2r))mr000-C2f(C1f+C2f)0aC2f(C1f+C2f)K1f(C1f+C2f)C1f(C1f+C2f)0-ChfC2f(C1f+C2f)0-aChfC2f(C1f+C2f)-ChfK1f(C1f+C2f)-ChfC1f(C1f+C2f)+Chf0+C2r(C1r+C2r)0-bC2f(C1r+C2r)000-ChrC2r(C1r+C2r)0bChrC2f(C1r+C2r)00]
(36)[Fx31]=[000Kr+K2r+(C2rK1r/(C1r+C2r))MC2rC1r/(C1r+C2r)M-C2fK1f/(C1f+C2f)M000b(-Kr-K2r-C2rK1r/(C1r+C2r))I-bC2rC1r/(C1r+C2r)I-aC2fK1f/(C1f+C2f)I00000C2K1f/(C1f+C2f)mf]

For the passive (semi-active MR suspension with 0 A) and semi-active suspension system the matrix [Fx1]=[[Fx11][Fx12]], [Fx2], [Fx3]=[[Fx31][Fx32]] and [Fx4]=[[Fx41][Fx42]] and they are respectively given by

sec.title: 2.5. Magneto rheological damper parameters
sec.p: The modified Bouc-Wen model includes the previous mentioned parameters (K1f, K2f, C1f, C2f, α1f) that depend on the applied current. In order to determine the corresponding functional dependencies, a GA is applied.

For different constant current values (u=0.02,0.06,0.1,0.2,0.4,0.6,0.8,1.05,1.5) in amper and cyclic imposed motion (frequency 1.67 Hz, amplitude 1 cm), the values of parameters (K1f, C2f, C1f, α1f) are determined by using GA. It is worth mentioning that damping and stiffness coefficients of the MR damper are comprised of some other constant parameters that have been mentioned in Section 2 and GA is employed to give those values. In the proposed method, the parameter finding is tackled as a black box optimization problem. It is well known that GAs are robust probabilistic search techniques with very good results in black box optimization. They are based on the mechanism of natural genetics and natural selection, start with an initial population of (encoded) problem solutions and evolve towards better solutions.

For the considered optimization procedure a real coded GA is employed (Agapie et al. 1998), with 11 real chromosome corresponding to the 11 coefficients: (K1f, K2f, C2fa, C2fb, C1fb, C1fa, α1fa, α1fb, β1f, γ1f, A1f). By using appropriate scaling factors, it can be assumed that the parameters take on values within the interval [0, 1]. In addition, other characteristics of applied GA are:
Average crossover with probability 0.8;
Uniform mutation and Monte Carlo selection;
Objective function is (37)f(x)=μ1[RMS(acceleration)]+μ2[max(acceleration)] +μ3[RMS(road holdingi)]i=front,rea μi is the proportion of road holding and acceleration in objective function. RMS in Equation 37, stands for Root mean square.
Applying the proposed GA, after about 500 generations, yields the values given in Table 2.
Table 2.
The parameters values obtained by genetic algorithm
Current (A) K1f[N/m] C1f[Ns/m] C2f[Ns/m] α1f[N/m]
0.02 527.2 407.3 4321 4196.2
0.06 306.7 427.5 4386.4 4262.1
0.1 223.3 447.2 4442.4 4326.3
0.2 468.4 508.9 4590.8 4484.2
0.4 988.1 593.7 4882.2 4765.2
0.6 1993.9 693.6 5178.1 5121.4
0.8 1242.3 791.3 5470.2 5438
1.05 1334.2 914.3 5836.2 5835.2
1.5 1630 1138.5 6418.8 6520.1
As was discussed earlier, K1f,r, C1f,r, C2f,r, α1f,r are functions of input current and by applying GA, it is possible to specify their values with change of electrical current.

Reji and Narayana (2005) used sinusoidal excitation with a stroke length of ±15mm and a fixed frequency of 1.67Hz to test a fabricated MR damper. The test is performed for 6cycles and for zero current and currents of0.5, 1.0 and 1.5Aas shown in Figure 5 (Prabakar et al., 2009). Furthermore, Narayana and Reji developed an objective function that was based on the difference between experimental forces and modeled forces generated by an MR damper. By using GA, the objective function was minimized and the constant values corresponding to Bouc-model was determined. As can be observed from Figure 5, there is a good agreement between experimental and theoretical outcomes. Figure 5.
Experimental dynamic behavior of fabricated magneto rheological damper.
(a) Force - time (b) Force - displacement (c) Force - velocity. Reproduced with kind permission from Elsevier (Prabakar et al., 2009).

To validate the experimental and theoretical results, the Narayanan study has been used in this research. As can be seen from Figure 6 the simulated behavior of the MR damper based on the Bouc-Wen model shows a close compliance with the experimental result of Reji and Narayana (2005). Figure 6.
Damper of Bouc-Wen method and experimental fabricated damper.

sec.title: 3. Fuzzy logic and fuzzy logic control
sec.p:
Fuzzy logic is powerful problem-solving methodology with a myriad of applications in embedded control and information processing. Fuzzy logic provides a remarkably simple way to draw definite conclusion from vague, ambiguous or imprecise information. In a sense, fuzzy logic resembles human decision making with its ability to work from an approximate date and find precise solutions. In general, the benefits of fuzzy controller can be stated as below:
Fuzzy controllers are more robust than proportional integral derivative (PID) controllers because they can cover a much wider range of operating conditions than PID, and can operate with noise and disturbances of different natures.
Developing a fuzzy controller is cheaper than developing a model-based or other controller to do the same thing.
Fuzzy controllers are customizable, since it is easier to understand and modify their rules, which not only use a human operator’s strategy but also are expressed in natural linguistic terms.
Here in this study, as mentioned previously, a fuzzy logic is used as a controller.

sec.title: 3.1. Characteristic parameters in fuzzy logic controller
sec.p:
To establish a fuzzy controller, parameters which should be specified, are the number and center values of the input and output membership functions (MFs) and linguistic control rules. In this paper, a demonstration is given of how to automate the design of a fuzzy logic controller. For generating membership function, generally, a chromosome similar to what has been shown in Figure 7 could be utilized. As can be seen, a long chromosome can make the intended algorithm for automating a fuzzy logic controller grueling and difficult to design. Based on what has been mentioned so as to simplify construction of fuzzy logic controller some assumptions should be taken into consideration. Some of these assumptions are helpful in designing controller that may be stated as follows (Park et al., 1995):
All universes of discourses are normalized to lie between −1 and 1 with scaling factors external to the FLC used to give appropriate values to the variables.
It is assumed that the first and last membership functions have their apexes at −1 and 1 respectively. This can be justified by the fact that changing the external scaling would have similar effect to changing these positions.
Only triangular membership functions are to be used.Using these constraints the design of the membership functions can be described using two parameters:
The number of membership functions.
The positioning of the triangle apexes.
Figure 7.
Chromosome data structure.

The spacing parameter is another parameter that specifies how the centers are spaced out across the universe of discourse. A value of one indicates even spacing, while a value larger than unity indicates that the membership functions are closer together in the center of the range and more spaced out at the extremes. The position of each center is calculated by using equation of (38) in which Pm indicates spacing parameters which are calculated automatically by GA. (38)Ømi=sign(i)[i(nmfs-12)]Pm

sec.title: 3.2. Developing fuzzy linguistic rules
sec.p: Construction of FLC is through parameters including numbers and center values of the input and output membership functions and linguistics control rules.

In designing rule-base by the help of ideas presented by Park et al. (1995), it is attempted to use a few number of variables for designing linguistic rules. To construct a rule base, spacing parameters for each variable and characteristic angle for each input variable are used to specify rule-base table. It is possible to divide the entire area of the rule table into the several areas which have the same influence. There is a relation between numbers of divided area and number of membership functions. The divided areas have been arranged with some guidelines as one of the membership functions. By observing a phase plane shown in the Figure 8 the aforementioned relation can be explained. The intersection point of grid lines represents fuzzy linguistic rules. Figure 8.
Characteristic parameters for linguistic rule table.

Accordingly the divided areas in the rule table can be also depicted in phase plane. In the phase plane, the divided areas can be separated by separating lines as can be seen in Figure 8. To construct a rule table with simpler design parameters, it is assumed that the separating line has been characterized by straight lines which are parallel to each other in the phase plane.

The origin is orthogonal to the separating lines. This straight line is defined as a seed line, and it includes seed points which have a meaning of linguistic rules. Accordingly, the linguistic rule in an intersection point of grid lines has been one of the nearest seed points. This means that the rule table can be obtained by determining the seed points. Therefore the characteristic parameters for the fuzzy linguistic rules can be obtained from the location of seed points. The locations of the seed points are determined by following the same procedure as for determining the center values of the membership functions. (39)xsi=L.sign(i).gs.|i|Ps
(40)ysi=xsi.tan(θs)
(41)(i=-n0+12,…,0,…,n0+12) where θs and Ps are seed angles measured in counter clock wise X-axis and the exponents of the power function, respectively. These parameters, θs and Ps are defined as the characteristic parameters for the fuzzy linguistic rules. Also, a positive valued coefficient gs can be obtained from the characteristic parameters Ps and the number of the output membership functions, n, according to equation (38). Finally, a range parameter L for limiting the locations of the seed points with the range of the phase plane can be obtained from the characteristic parameters θs as follows: (42)L={1×sign(tan(θs))if|1/tan(θs)|≥11/tan(θs)otherwise

Since the FLC has been represented with a few characteristic parameters such as Ps, n, θs, and Pm which are defined as in the above explanations, optimal FLC can easily be obtained through the optimization of the characteristic parameters.

sec.title: 3.3. Encoding parameters
sec.p:
To run a GA, a suitable deciphering for each of parameters and bounds for each of them need to be decided. For this task, the parameters given in Table 3 are used with shown ranges and precisions. Binary encoding is used as it is felt that this allows the GA to search the solution space more thoroughly. Table 3.
Parameters of encoding
Parameter Range Precision No. of bits
Number of membership functions 3–9 2 2
Membership function spacing 0.1–1.0 0.01 7
Membership function spacing (power to be raised by) −1–1 2 1
Rule-base scaling 0.1–1.0 0.01 7
Rule-base spacing (power to be raised by) −1–1 2 1
Input scaling 0–100 0.1 10
Output scaling 0–10000 0.1 17
Rule-base angle 0–2π π/512 11

sec.title: 3.4. Development of fuzzy logic control system
sec.p:
To design a controller which provides an ultimate ride comfort while not undermining handling, it would be plausible to combine two different controllers, a controller which is based on the ride comfort and another one which aims to increase the handling by road holding. Figure 9 develops such a controller which satisfies targets, i.e., ride comfort and handling demands; two different objectives functions that is each designed independently and optimized by using the aforementioned GA. Figure 9.
Combined fuzzy controller for improving handling and rid comfort.

An objective function used for deriving a fuzzy logic controller which is based on enhancing ride comfort is shown in equation (43). Weight coefficients in equation (43) are considered in a way that can maximize the role of acceleration and angular acceleration in optimizing an objection function. To reach an optimum result the algorithm is performed for three different population sizes and then the best fitness function is saved. (43)eff=[(Rms(θ'))∧(-1)+3.6(max(θ'))∧(-1)] +[1.15(Rms(Z'_s))∧(-1)+5.6(max(Z'_s))∧(-1)] +0.015(Rms[road holding front])∧(-1)
In developing a fuzzy logic controller, the use of few fuzzy rules is taken into consideration in order to make the controller less expensive and applicable.

Figure 10 depicts two inputs and one output of the controller designed for increasing ride comfort. As it can be seen, inputs and outputs are in the range of [−1,1]. To transform this interval to a real one some gains are used which are designed by GA simultaneously with designing membership and fuzzy rules. Figure 10.
Input and output membership functions. (a) Membership function of the first input (Z·us-Z·road). (b) Membership function of the second input (Z·s-Z·us) (c) Output membership function.

When the main aim of the controller is the increasing amount of adhesiveness of tire to ground another objective function that puts the emphasis on road holding is needed. The objective function used for increasing road holding is shown in equation (44). Membership functions and fuzzy rules generated based on the aforementioned multi objective function are depicted in Figure 11 and Table 5. (44)fitness=(RMS[road holding front])-1 +(RMS[road holding rear])-1 +max(road holding front)
Figure 11.
Input and output membership functions. (a) Membership function of first input (Z·us-Z·road). (b) Membership function of the second input (Z·s-Z·us). (c) Output membership function.
Table 4.
Basic fuzzy rules for enhancing ride comfort
NBNSZEPBPS
NB PS PS ZE NS NS
NS PB PS ZE NS NS
ZE PB PB ZE NS PB
PS PB ZE NB NS PB
PB PB PB ZE NB NB
Table 5.
Basic fuzzy rules for enhancing handling
NB NS ZE PB PS
NB NB NB NB NB NS
NS NS NS ZE PS PS
ZE PS PB PB PB PB

sec.title: 3.5. Development of fuzzy preview control (FLC-P)
sec.p: Preview control can decrease both the overshoot and the control energy of the system. There are many approaches on preview control; however, as these approaches are based on linearized models, they cannot get a good result when they are applied to nonlinear plants as described by Aida (2003). So a fuzzy preview controls compensate the nonlinear properties of the plant. Here in this study a new designing scheme of preview control element using fuzzy theory is proposed and the preview control element is optimized with GA.

The use of preview information in the suspension system is made under the assumption that the vehicle operating parameters and the preview information from on-board sensors are readily available. The preview system is able to account for the motions of the vehicle when predicting the terrain profile ahead of the vehicle. Note the feed forward portion in Figures 12 and 14, uses the future message, Δrp(k) defined as equations (45) and (46) and produces desired output. (45)Δrp(k)=∑i=1Lpwi[r(k+i)-r(k)]∑i=1Lpwi
(46)Lp=tpΔtp where wi is weight. Choosing Gaussian function, it is defined as equation (47). (47)wi=e-(i-C)22σ2
Figure 12.
Semi-active suspension system with preview.
Figure 13.
Membership function applied for preview controller. a) Antecedent. b) Consequent.Figure 3.
Power spectral density of stochastic road surface models as function of frequency and vehicle velocity for rough second order filtered model.Figure 4.
Magneto rheological damper, (a) Schematic representation, (b) Actual hardware. Figure 14.
Block diagram for control system with feedback and feed-forward.

Equations (44) and (45) mean that the further the massage is, the weaker it works to preview control action in current time. FLC-P in Figure 14 means FLC for preview control, whose output produce incremental output Δup(t). Here, it is considered MFs for both antecedent and consequent are triangular. Because FLC of a triangle type is used for preview control element’s design, the FLC-P must ensure that Δup(k)=0 when Δrp(k)=0. To do this, the simplest method is to let MFs for antecedent and consequent be symmetrical (Aida, 2003).

To preview the control element, it is not enough to design the FLC only, but how to determine preview step number LP is also important. A suitable LP cannot only let the response of the system be faster and less overshoot.

sec.title: 4. Frequency domain
sec.p: For a multiple degrees-of-freedom system, its frequency response characteristic is the complex number ratio of response vector and excitation vector. For the half-car, the transfer function would be like equation (48): (48)[SZ(ω)]=[[H(ω)][Sw(ω)][H*(ω)]T] where, Sw(ω) is the spectral density function matrix of excitation, SZ(ω) is the spectral density function matrix of the responses and H*(ω) is the complex conjugate of the transfer function.
Furthermore, from equation (20) the transfer function can be achieved as equation (49). (49)H(ω)=1/1(jωId-F) where Id is identity matrix and j=-1.

sec.title: 5. Results and discussion
sec.p: Semi-active suspension with an MR damper, passive and active fuzzy control system are investigated under the road excitations simulated based on what has been presented in the road simulation section. Control of the MR damper is very important for all applications. Because the MR damper force cannot be directly controlled, then, the applied voltage can be controlled which in turn can be directly done to operate the MR damper. To achieve that, an inverse model may be built. It predicts the voltage required to be applied to the current driver to produce a desired force with known displacement and velocity. Desired force for an MR damper is provided with active fuzzy control. The RMS sprung mass acceleration, RMS pitch acceleration, RMS front and rear suspension strokes, road holdings, control forces, input currents and overall performances are computed for the vehicle with the (a) passive suspension (MR damper with 0 A) (b) active suspension system based on fuzzy control without preview (c) active suspension system based on fuzzy control with preview (d) semi-active suspension with MR damper and mean square equivalent control force of fuzzy control without preview (e) semi-active suspension with MR damper and mean square equivalent control force of fuzzy control with preview. The responses related to the fuzzy active suspension system and the semi-active suspension equipped with MR damper and with mean square equivalent control force of fuzzy control without preview system are provided by setting the preview distance, PD=0.

For implementation of the controller and simulation of the system designed following parameters have been considered. M=1200kg, mf=75g, mr=80kg, I=1800kgm2, Kf=30kN/m, Kr=30kN/m, Cf=400Ns/m, Cr=450Ns/m, Ktf=300kN/m, Ktr=300kN/m, a=1.011m, b=1.803m.

Figures 15 and 16 indicate the input currents to the front and rear MR dampers corresponding to the mean square equivalence of the control forces with fuzzy controller with and without preview. As it can be deduced from those mentioned figures, the input current required for matching the fuzzy control force with preview is more than input current needed for matching the fuzzy control without preview; because the control force required for the active suspension system with preview is more than the control force without preview system. Figure 15.
Input current to front magneto rheological damper corresponding to mean square equivalence of active suspension control force.
Figure 16.
Input current to rear magneto rheological damper corresponding to mean square equivalence of active suspension control force.

Figure 17 depicts The RMS control forces produced by the MR damper for input currents shown in Figure 15. In addition, Figure 17 represents the control force generated by fuzzy control without and with preview. The trends of control force of the active, semi-active and passive system are presenting very good harmony between each other. The control force corresponding to the passive suspension system (MR damper with 0 A) is also shown in Figure 17. Figure 17.
RMS of front control force (a) Passive (b) Fuzzy without preview (c) Fuzzy with preview (d) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (e) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview.

The performance of passive, active suspension with fuzzy controller, semi-active suspension system with MR damper with considering equation (42) are taken to account in Figure 18. What can be inferred from Figure 18 is the overall efficiency of the system with MR damper, not only is far better than passive system but also to what extent it can measure itself against the system equipped with fuzzy controller. Figure 18.
Overall performance of the vehicle for different control methods (a) Passive (b) Fuzzy without preview (c) Fuzzy with preview (d) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (e) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview.

As it can be inferred, the performance expected from MR damper does not measure up to the performance of the fuzzy control especially at higher velocities. The performance of the MR damper with mean square control force equivalent to the fuzzy control force with preview has the edge over the performance of the MR damper with the mean square control force equivalent to the control force without preview. As may be seen from Figure 18, the performance with fuzzy control with preview is better than the performance with fuzzy control without preview.

Figure 19 shows that the sprung mass acceleration in MR damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without and with preview performs better than the passive suspension, but generally active suspension with fuzzy control without and with preview is more successful in controlling vibration transmitted through roads. As it is depicted in Figure 19, the preview information improves the ride comfort by decreasing acceleration. Generally, preview control has a fair influence on the ride comfort. Figure 19.
RMS of sprung mass acceleration response (a) Passive (b) Fuzzy without preview (c) Fuzzy with preview (d) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (e) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview.

Pitch acceleration as it is demonstrated in Figure 20, shows improvement when the preview along with the MR damper is employed. The RMS value of the pitch acceleration is plotted for different vehicle velocities in Figure 20. Similar trends as for the sprung mass acceleration response are observed in this case too. The performance of the MR damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview is better than corresponding to the mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview. The fuzzy controls without and with preview perform better than the corresponding MR damper suspension. As can be inferred, the performance of the MR damper in terms of pitch acceleration and sprung mass acceleration is much better than the performance of the passive suspension. Figure 20.
RMS of sprung mass pitch response (a) Passive (b) Fuzzy without preview (c) Fuzzy with preview (d) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (e) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview.

The RMS of front suspension strokes for all control cases are shown in Figure 21. In this case also the suspension with mean square control force equivalent to the fuzzy control force without and with preview performs better than the passive suspension. But the performances do not measure up to the performances of the corresponding active suspension with fuzzy control without and with preview. Furthermore, front suspension stroke when the suspension is equipped with MR damper and preview system in terms of efficiency is in part better than active suspension without preview as can be seen in Figure 21. Figure 21.
RMS of front suspension stroke response (a) Passive (b) Fuzzy without preview (c) Fuzzy with preview (d) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (e) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview.

The rear RMS of suspension stroke responses is shown in Figure 22. In this case, the MR damper suspension performances with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without and with preview are much better than the corresponding fuzzy control performance and also much better than the passive suspension performance. As can be seen, the fuzzy control force performance without preview is worse than that of the passive suspension. This may be due to the fact that the weighting factors in the performance index determined in favor of the preview information. Moreover, the performance index with respect to the suspension strokes is a combination of both the front and rear suspension strokes and does not consider them individually. Because of this, it may be possible that the rear suspension stroke is not properly weighted in the performance index and hence its performance is degraded in the control scheme. Figure 22.
RMS suspension stroke response at rear (a) Passive (b) Fuzzy without preview (c) Fuzzy with preview (d) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (e) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview.

This deterioration in performance is alleviated slightly with the preview information. The RMS of road holding response at front is plotted for all the control schemes as a function of velocity in Figure 23. As can be observed, MR damper with preview system can enhance efficiency of the system in terms of road holding and finally handling of a vehicle can improve. Figure 23.
RMS road holding response (a) Fuzzy with preview (b) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force without preview (c) Magneto rheological damper with mean square equivalent fuzzy control force with preview (d) Passive (e) Fuzzy without preview.

Again it is worth mentioning that because the performance index is designed so that ride comfort has more importance than handling, the controller with the aim of improvement of road holding and as a result enhancing maneuverability of the vehicle, is not to a large extent successful.

Figure 24 shows the RMS of sprung mass acceleration for different suspension system in frequency domain. Four predominant frequencies are observed in the Figures 24 and 25. As it can be seen, third and fourth predominant frequencies are close to each other. It is obvious that sprung mass acceleration as compared to the passive suspension is improved by active and semi-active suspension system. RMS of pitch acceleration response for different suspension system is plotted in Figure 25. It is observed all control schemes perform better than passive suspension system at all frequencies. Figure 24.
Sprung mass acceleration in frequency domain.
Figure 25.
Pitch acceleration in frequency domain.

sec.title: 6. Preview time effects
sec.p: The vehicles moving with different velocities lead to the variation of preview time. If the sensor that is mounted in the front bumper could see 2.4 m ahead, the preview time is 0.12 s for the vehicle velocity of 20 m/s (72 km/h). To study the effect of preview time, performance of the system in terms of vertical and pitch accelerations have been compared over the range of preview time from 0.01 to 0.19 s.

It is also observed from Figure 26 that additional increase in the preview time does not produce significant improvement in the performance index. Also, it is demonstrated that optimal preview time is around 0.11 (s) that provide both RMS of accelerations in a suitable performance. Figure 26.
Performance with respect to preview time.

sec.title: 7. Robustness analysis of the system
sec.p: Different operating conditions and a variation in system parameters can influence the output performance. To ensure robustness, modeling of such systems requires uncertain parameters to be dealt with as interval quantities. A suspension system is a type of system that has inherent variation in some of its parameters. These parameters include, mass, payload, stiffness and damping coefficient. Hence, the interval parameter concept plays an important role in the control of automotive vehicle suspension system. Here, the system robustness is evaluated by employing Monte Carlo method. Not to mention the operation of the suspension system design is affected by change in the mass distribution of the car. To be robust, the system must be insensitive to changes in mass distribution and other parameters that can affect the whole system, controller and suspension system. It is assumed that the mass distribution of front and rear axle load follow Rayleigh distributions randomly sample the distributions to define conditions to test our design performance.

Figure 27 depicts a scatter matrix plot that summarizes variability seen in discomfort as a result of different mass loading for the robust design case. The diagonals show a histogram of the variable listed on the axis. The histograms for front and back represent the distribution of the inputs to our simulation. Figure 27.
Discomfort distribution as a result of different mass loading.

The histogram for discomfort shows that it is concentrated around the value 0.52 and is approximately normally distributed. There is a definite trend associated with the front loading on discomfort. Front loading appears to be approximately linear with a minimum of 0.45 and a maximum of 0.53. Using a cumulative probability plot of the discomfort results as shown in Figure 28, it is estimated that most of the time, passengers will experience less than 50% of the discomfort they would have experienced with the initial design that was the system without a controller. It may also be observed that the new design maintains a normalized level of discomfort below 0.54 nearly 100% of the time. Accordingly, it is concluded that the optimized design has robustness with respect to loading variation and will perform better than the system without a controller. Figure 28.
Cumulative probability plot of the discomfort results.

sec.title: 8. Conclusions
sec.p: The current paper, dealing with a rather new comparative study, is trying to find out the suitable way of controlling and isolating all the vibrations passing through the road as the source of excitation. The MR damper performance is sought to be enhanced in as much as the performance of active suspensions with fuzzy control without and with preview. A new method to determine the weighting factors in the performance index in fuzzy control using a multi-objective optimization procedure is presented. The equivalent linearization method is used to get the response of the vehicle with MR damper which is modeled by the modified Bouc-Wen model.

Results show that the performance of the MR suspension improves with preview information and better than the performance of the passive suspension. The performance of the MR damper suspension with respect to sprung mass acceleration and pitch acceleration does not measure up to the corresponding performances of active suspension with fuzzy control without and with preview. The suspension stroke and road holding performances especially at the rear are almost as good as the performances of the active suspension with fuzzy control without and with preview. Generally speaking, on the basis of the results presented, the following conclusions are drawn:
The model used for simulation of MR damper is up to a certain point precise and acceptable for the present application.
The present results substantiate the earlier findings that properly designed active suspensions with preview are highly effective in reducing the performance index and the mean square responses during the vehicle travel on a random road.
Conformability of active system with preview is better than a system including MR damper and preview sensors.
The advantage of magneto rheological dampers is the low power input requirements and the high output force that they could produce.

def.p: Control force generated by the magneto rheological dampers

Stiffness coefficient in the magneto rheological damper simulation

Damping coefficient in the magneto rheological damper simulation

Equivalent damping coefficient for the front and rear damper

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
